1.text: "The present paper defends the thesis that Spenser's recovery of place

2.text: "Traditional humanism is sometimes defined as an attempt to appropriate the meaning of classical art and literature in terms of "timeless" philosophical truths."

3.text: "Spenser's originality as a Renaissance poet has much to do with his use of literary procedures that express but also complicate his relationship to traditional humanism."

4.text: "The heart of Spenser's "Book of Courtesy" enacts a Neo-Platonic movement from the lower levels of temporal existence to an exalted vision of spiritual perfection."

5.text: "This same section can be read along phenomenological lines as a mysterious adventure that embraces self and other

6.text: "The burden of this paper is largely concerned with demonstrating how this poetic sequence instates the "truth" of place in a way that is inseparable from the meaning of Spenser's humanism."

7.text: "Spenser's celebration of Courtesy as a virtue involves an appreciation of social values as well as a commitment to transcendent notions of Good."

8.text: "This peculiar combination cannot be understood apart from a dialectical appraisal of Spenser's view of nature."

9.text: "Spenser identifies nature with the principle of fecundity and abundance."

10.text: "Spenser also maintains that nature can function as the invisible source of moral virtue."

11.text: "The difference between these two conceptions of nature can be understood in terms of the tension that governs The Faerie Queene as a whole."

12.text: "The Aristotelian conception is more closely related to traditional conceptions of political authority."

15.text: "The idea that virtue can be institutional as well as basic to human communities underlines Spenser's epic narrative as a recovery of place which happens in language and ultimately concerns the movement of the soul toward imaginative fulfillment."

16.text: "In the introductory stanzas of his epic

17.text: "Courtesy as a virtue belongs in the hall of princes

18.text: "An early allusion to the meaning of courtesy invokes the figure of Calidore."

20.text: "The figure of Calidore takes part in a phenomenological movement toward spiritual insight."

21.text: "While functioning as a counter to pure nature and its attendant virtue

22.text: "Calidore's moral education within the epic context takes the form of a "recollection" of virtue that allows him to partially overcome the difference between nature and politics."

24.text: "Calidore's absence creates a moral vacuum that his return promises to fill."

25.text: "Calidore's return to the center of the poem has not gone unobserved."

26.text: "Calidore's return promises to fill the moral vacuum created by his absence."

27.text: "The recovery of place involves a slow spiritual awakening that embraces the lowest levels of erotic awareness as well as the highest reaches of "ideal" experience."

28.text: "The recovery of place becomes a sublime metaphor whose deeper meaning is corroborated by tradition and phenomenology alike."
